name: Abandoned 4 - the genesis block.
description:
This post I traced back to the first time I captured essentially abandoned food. It’s so strange what people dump. The way they leave it, the things they leave. Were they in a rush? 

I was going to post a life sketch of a set of drawers, and two seperate people said I should mint the rubbish I see instead, so I thought it fitting to include the photo and post that started it all. 

Fascinating that I’d post it on Instagram ‘for free’ 7 years ago. Free at the cost of my data, where now I have spent $20 to post a view of my world, and that those people who liked ‘for free’ at the cost of their data, would have to pay tez to engage instead. 

When I took this photo I thought that Facebook likes would eventually replace money. Now after seeing NFTs emerge I’m wondering if money will replace likes. 

And by money I guess I mean tokens of labour, value, attention, abstracted and transacted on networks with nothing to gain, nothing to lose, and no way to change without a confluence of the above.

Networks that let me immortalise abandoned food, so anyone looking back can see us as we really were. Strange, busy, momentary creatures, with unfathomable motivations and desires.
